_comment: Created by JMorris on 09/05/2018 14:43:41 using v2.7
title: How does five-year cervical cancer survival in the UK compare to other countries?
analysis_commentary:
Cervical cancer is highly preventable if detected and treated before progression occurs. The main cause of cervical cancer is sexual exposure to human papilloma virus (HPV). About half of OECD countries have cervical screening programmes and around half have implemented HPV vaccination programmes.

International trends in five-year cervical cancer survival show more cross country variation over time than for five-year breast cancer survival. While survival has been improving in the UK, the country is still one of the worst performers compared to other OECD countries, with a five-year survival of only 63.8% in 2010-2014. This is despite a relatively high cervical cancer screening coverage. In comparison, survival in Denmark in the same time period was 69.5% while survival in Japan reached 71.4%.

Updated April 2018.
data_source: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Health Care Quality Indicators, Cancer Care
